Title: Nick Kyrgios reveals when he plans to return to tennis after missing Wimbledon and the French Open
Description:
Nick Kyrgios had hoped to play Wimbledon in 2025, but was forced to withdraw due to injury.

The 30-year-old picked up an injury before the grass-court season, which led to Kyrgios withdrawing from Wimbledon.

Kyrgios had already skipped the French Open in June as fans await the Aussie's return to Grand Slam action.

Working as a pundit for TalkSport at Wimbledon this year, the 2022 finalist continues to be involved with tennis.

It may not be too long until we see him back on the court, however, as Kyrgios now reveals when he plans to return.

Speaking to Former doubles number one Jamie Murray on ‘Wimbledon Unfiltered with Nick Kyrgios', the world number 637 updated fans on his injury status.

“Well, I was supposed to be back for Wimbledon, but I had a bit of a knee niggle three weeks ago, so just trying to get back for the US swing,” said Kyrgios.

“I think we're both in the twilight of our careers, but look, I really want to come back, I'm hitting the ball great.

“Had a bit of a session today, feeling good.”

The US swing Kyrgios is referring to begins in Washington later this month and finishes at Flushing Meadows in September.

Kyrgios has enjoyed real success at those tournaments over the years, winning the Washington Open on two occasions and reaching the Cincinnati Open final in 2017.

If he can recover from injury in time, what better place to return than Washington, a tournament Kyrgios has won twice before.

Regardless of where he returns, Kyrgios will no doubt hope to start racking up the wins on the ATP Tour before too long.

Playing his first competitive match in over a year, Kyrgios returned to tennis at the Brisbane International, where he lost in three tight sets to big-server Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.

Another defeat followed in Melbourne, when Kyrgios lost to Jacob Fearnley 6-7, 3-6, 6-7.

Beginning his year with an 0-3 run, Kyrgios retired down 6-7, 0-3, to Botic van de Zandschulp at Indian Wells.

It was at his next tournament that Kyrgios finally returned to winning ways, when he took to the court for his opening match at the Miami Open.

After dropping the first set 3-6, Kyrgios fought back to beat Mackenzie McDonald 3-6, 6-3, 6-4 to book his place in round two.

Having secured his first win in 895 days, Kyrgios was unable to back it up in the second round, as he fell to Karen Khachanov 6-7, 0-6.

He hasn't played another match on tour since, as Kyrgios currently has a 1-4 record in 2025.

With just 50 ATP points to his name, Kyrgios is currently ranked 637th in the world, a long way from his career-high ranking of 13th.

Only time will tell if Kyrgios can shoot back up the rankings when he returns later this year, but it will most certainly be worth tuning in for.

Kyrgios may well return at the Washington Open ATP 500 event, which is scheduled to begin on Monday, July 21.

Title: Sabalenka, Gauff headline women's entry list for National Bank Open in Montreal
Description:
Adjust preferences

With your consent we may collect cookies and information to enhance our service, and improve your experience.


					These cookies and data are essential for browsing our website and allowing services. Examples include, session, authentication, and security cookies.


					These cookies and data enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalized content.


					These cookies and data inform us which pages are most informative and engaging via analytics.


					These cookies may track data across websites for marketing and interest-based advertising to provide personalized content, offers, and advertisements.

Montreal


			By The Canadian Press		

Posted July 3, 2025 12:26 pm.

Aryna Sabalenka and Coco Gauff headline a star-studded women's field for the National Bank Open in Montreal, Tennis Canada announced Thursday.

The world No. 1 and No. 2 are scheduled to take centre stage at IGA Stadium in a field that's also set to include two-time defending champion Jessica Pegula.

The WTA's top 68 competitors are poised to compete as part of a 96-player main draw — the largest in the event's history — as the annual showcase enters its new 12-day format.

Sabalenka, a three-time Grand Slam champion, has posted a 44-8 record so far in 2025, including victories in Miami and Madrid, along with an appearance in the French Open final.

Gauff, who defeated Sabalenka at Roland-Garros for her second Grand Slam win, owns a 31-10 record this season.

There will be at least three Canadians in the main draw, with Leylah Fernandez (No. 38) of Laval, Que., set to make her sixth NBO appearance. Toronto's Victoria Mboko, who was eliminated in the second round at Wimbledon on Thursday, and Bianca Andreescu of Mississauga, Ont., have both been awarded wild-card berths.

Pegula became the first woman to capture back-to-back NBO titles since Martina Hingis in 2000 when she triumphed in Toronto last summer. The world No. 3 has added titles in Charleston, Austin and Bad Homburg to her resume this season, marking the first time she's won three tournaments in a single campaign.

Iga Swiatek (No. 4), Jasmine Paolini (No. 5), Qinwen Zheng (No. 6), Mirra Andreeva (No. 7), Madison Keys (No. 8), Paula Badosa (No. 9), and Emma Navarro (No. 10) are also scheduled to take part in the Canadian event.

Other notable names include past Canadian champions Elina Svitolina (No. 13) and Belinda Bencic (No. 35), along with three Wimbledon winners — Barbora Krejcikova (No. 16), Marketa Vondrousova (No. 73) and Elena Rybakina (No. 11).

The first NBO under the new format begins with qualifying July 26. Main-draw play runs July 27 through Aug. 7. The top 32 seeds will receive first-round byes and will begin play July 29 or July 30.

Title: 'Well I'm shocked'
Description:
Arthur Fery will hope a Wimbledon court supervisor's 'surprising' decision can rescue him from the jaws of defeat.

The British star trailed 6-4, 6-3 in his second round match against Luciano Dardieri when he received what may prove to be divine intervention.

As the pair walked back to their chairs at the end of the second set, the match supervisor strolled onto Court 2 and made the executive decision to postpone the contest due to bad light, with the match to resume on Thursday afternoon.

The call was made at 8:45pm, although play had continued through to 9:15pm on previous evenings in SW19.

BBC commentary duo Matt Chilton and Dom Inglot were left baffled by the supervisor's decision to bring an end to Wednesday's proceedings earlier than usual.

"There is a collective groan around the ground now," Chilton said.

"That is a little surprising that at quarter-to-nine, play is suspended."

Inglot replied: "Well I am shocked. If I was Darderi I would be carrying on as long as I possibly could.

"He is playing some unbelievable tennis right now.

"You never know, he could come back tomorrow and not be feeling it like he is right now."

Chilton added: "They have been going on till much later than this.

"However, the decision has been made and these two will return to this court tomorrow."

Fery, 22, reached the second round at Wimbledon thanks to a stunning upset over 20th seed Alexei Popyrin.

It marked the first time Fery won a match at a grand slam.

But the world No. 481 will have it all to do against Darderi when their game resumes.

Fery and Darderi are not the only stars to have had their match postponed until the following day at this year's Wimbledon.

American star Taylor Fritz's gruelling first round encounter against powerful Frenchman Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard had to be pushed to the next day, but not because of bad light.

Instead, it was due to the 11pm curfew in place.

Fritz and Mpetshi Perricard had played an energy-sapping four sets - three of which were tiebreaks - under the closed roof on Centre Court when the umpire called an end to proceedings for the night as the 11pm deadline loomed.

It was not a decision Fritz wanted as he was keen to continue playing through to 11pm, but Mpetshi Perricard was not.

"They told us before the match, 'Hey, are you good to play 'til 11? We're going to stop at 11,' " Fritz said.

"When I'm looking at the clock at the end of the fourth set, I'm thinking, 'Oh, it's 10, there's no way they're going to stop us. We're forsure playing this fifth set.'

"The idea of stopping wasn't even in my mind. I was fully tunnel- visioned on this match is finishing tonight.

"What happened was, I get it -- we both have to agree. If we don't, then the referee makes a decision. What I didn't understand, the referee, after he said what his decision was, he kept asking me. I think he just wanted me to, like, agree with him.

"I said, 'I don't know why you keep asking me, because I want to play. Stop asking me, because you already said we're not playing.' "

Fritz and Mpetshi Perricard returned the following day to finish off the contest 6-7 (6-8), 6-7 (8-10), 6-4, 7-6 (8-6), 6-4.

Things didn't get much easier for the American in the second round as he prevailed in another taxing five-set encounter, this time against Canada's Gabriel Diallo.

Title: Which British tennis players are still in Wimbledon?
Description:
A record number of British singles tennis players advanced past day one of this year's Wimbledon.

Now four days into the Grand Slam tournament, how is the home-grown talent faring in SW19?

Jack Draper

Leading the charge for a British Grand Slam champion this year is Jack Draper.

The British men's No 1 - who entered Wimbledon ranked No 4 in the world - cruised into the second round after seeing off Argentina's Sebastian Baez.

However, he faces a tougher test against former US Open winner Marin Cilic next on Court One on Thursday.

Draper is officially in the midst of a breakout after winning three titles over the last year, among those being the Masters 1000 event at Indian Wells in March.

But speaking ahead of his second-round Wimbledon match, the 23-year-old said he isn't particularly feeling the pressure just yet.

He said: "I obviously was aware of the build up and all that sort of stuff, but I think my preparation has been really good and I feel confident, so I'm not thinking too much about that."

Read more:How much do tennis players earn in prize money at Wimbledon?Meet the three British teenagers handed Wimbledon wildcards

Cameron Norrie

Cameron Norrie has already booked his place in the third round of Wimbledon after knocking out 12th seed Frances Tiafoe.

The former British number one came close to dropping out of the top 100 earlier this season but entered SW19 ranked 61 in the world.

And not being in the top 10 has meant Norrie is enjoying tennis "more than ever".

He said: "I think it's a good thing to go through being injured, not winning, then having resilience to back yourself. I'm enjoying my tennis more than ever. It was really nice coming up to get into the top 10 but it's just tough, really tough, to stay there."

Norrie plays Mattia Bellucci in the third round on Friday.

Emma Raducanu

The current British women's No 1 has started her Wimbledon campaign strong, defeating former champion Marketa Vondrousova to reach the third round.

Emma Raducanu was left grinning after the 6-3 6-3 win that has set up what is due to be a blockbuster third-round clash with world No 1 Aryna Sabalenka on Friday.

Speaking ahead of the third round, the 22-year-old said: "I'm just so happy I get to play another match here. [Sabalenka] is number one in the world, so dominant, has won literally everything.

"I'm just so happy how I performed. I guess there's no pressure at all on me."

Sonay Kartal

Sonay Kartal appears to be in with a good chance of making the fourth round of a Grand Slam for the first time as she takes on qualifier Diane Parry next at Wimbledon.

The 23-year-old followed up her defeat of 20th seed Jelena Ostapenko by racing to a 6-2 6-2 win over Bulgarian Viktoriya Tomova to make it to the last 32.

Reflecting on her performance over Tomova, the British hopeful said she was pleased with her play.

She said: "I don't think I did much wrong at all. I was seeing it really well. I felt confident. I feel like I was playing really aggressive tennis."

Dan Evans

Home-grown hopeful Dan Evans was knocked out of this year's tournament by seven-time champion Novak Djokovic.

The pair battled it out on Centre Court on Thursday, with the Serb winning in straight sets.

"I knew it was going to be a special atmosphere on the court today, a Brit in Britain is never easy to face," Djokovic said after the match.

"He's a good quality player that possesses a lot of talent."

Evans had won their only previous career meeting, in Monte Carlo four years ago.

He had arrived at this year's Wimbledon as a wild card, ranking No 154 in the world.

Katie Boulter

Despite expertly navigating her way into the second round of Wimbledon, Katie Boulter suffered defeat against Argentina's Solana Sierra.

The loss means she has still never progressed beyond the third round at any of the sport's four major tournaments. It is also the second time in a row she has not made it beyond the second round at Wimbledon

"Of course it hurts, it's a really tough pill to swallow - it always is here," said Boulter, who may yet end the tournament back at British number one.

Arthur Fery

British wild card Arthur Fery was unable to mount a comeback as his second-round tie with Luciano Darderi, which started on Wednesday, resumed on Thursday on Court Two with the Italian two sets up.

Darderi took the third set to secure a 6-4 6-3 6-3 victory in two hours and 21 minutes.

Title: Wimbledon LIVE: Emma Raducanu rumour gathers pace as fellow Brit set to lose prize money
Description:
It's been an entertaining start to Wimbledon, with plenty of big names falling in the early rounds of the men's and women's draws. The likes of Coco Gauff, Qinwen Zheng and Daniil Medvedev all lost their opening matches, leaving the competition wide open. There was no such misfortune for Emma Raducanu, who did brilliantly to beat Marketa Vondrousova in the second round.

Raducanu will face a tough test against Aryna Sabalenka in round three, while Jack Draper will be hoping to beat Marin Cilic later today. Novak Djokovic, meanwhile, will go up against Dan Evans with high hopes of upsetting the British crowd on Centre Court. The other big-name players in action on day four include Iga Swiatek, Jannik Sinner and Mirra Andreeva.

Express Sport brings you all the latest news from Wimbledon...

Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions, and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. Read our Privacy Policy

We use your sign-up to provide content in ways you've consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and 3rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. Read our Privacy Policy

Tommy Paul called the physio and received a mid-game medical time-out in the second set of his match against Sebastian Ofner when he appeared to pull his foot while jumping for an overhead.

He had his foot strapped up at 4-4. But he's since dropped the second and third set after taking the opener.

Ofner leads the 13th seed 1-6 7-5 6-4.

There are plenty of top players in trouble right now. But five-time Major winner Iga Swiatek has made sure she won't fall victim to an upset on Thursday.

The eighth seed came back from a set down to beat Caty McNally 5-7 6-2 6-1 on Centre Court.

No. 4 seed Jack Draper is on the cusp of going out over on Court 1.

And another top player is at risk. 28th seed Sofia Kenin lost the first set of her second-round match 6-1 to Jessica Bouzas Maneiro - the dangerous Spaniard who is known for causing upsets at Majors.

Jack Draper is now two sets down over on Court 1.

Cameron Norrie is the only British man into round three at Wimbledon and at this rate, the world No.4 Draper won't be joining him.

Maric Cilic took the first set 6-4 and he takes this second one 6-3.

Draper needs a massive, massive effort to get back into this. Croatian veteran Cilic, 36, is on fire.



British No. 1 Jack Draper is in some serious trouble over on Court 1.

The fourth seed trails Marin Cilic by a set and a break. Cilic, a former world No. 3, won the US Open in 2014 and made the final here three years later.

But he's since slipped down the rankings after battling injuries on-and-off for years.

There's another medical time-out on Court 3, this time for Tommy Paul. The physio is treating his foot after he appeared to tweak something in the middle of a game.

It's 4-4 30-15 on the American's serve but he's now having his left foot bandaged up after landing awkwardly on it when he jumped for an overhead.



She's had to do it in three sets again, but defending champion an 17th seed Barbora Krejcikova is through to the third round after beating Caroline Dolehide 6-4 3-6 6-2.

She meets world No. 10 Emma Navarro for a spot in the second week.

The seeds just keep on falling here at Wimbledon - and we could see another bow out.

Eighth seed and five-time Major winner Iga Swiatek has lost the first set of her match against Caty McNally 7-5 on Centre Court. The former world No. 1 led by a break before falling away.

Sebastian Ofner has called the physio after losing the first set 6-1 to Tommy Paul over on Court 3 and he's now having a medical time out to have his right wrist strapped up.



Alex de Minaur has admitted it was tough to reset ahead of his own match after watching his fiance, British No. 2 Katie Boulter, suffer a crushing defeat on Wednesday.

“It's not ideal. It's not nice. I felt for Katie yesterday, and I've been in those positions myself. It's not easy by any means to, yeah, forget about it. It's something that kind of stays with you,” the Aussie said after beating Arthur Cazaux 4-6 6-2 6-4 6-0.

“It definitely does have a little bit of impact on yourself, and you've got to do your best to try and have a mental reset and kind of shift your focus towards yourself and realising that you do have a match the following day that you've got to prepare for, it's not going to be an easy one, it's going to be a battle.”

Grigor Dimitrov booked his spot in the third round of Wimbledon with a 7-5 4-6 7-5 7-5 victory over Corentin Moutet over on Court 3.

It's been a positive start to Wimbledon for former semi-finalist Dimitrov, who has been forced to retire injured from the last four Grand Slam tournaments. He awaits the winner of Sebastian Ofner vs Tommy Paul.



Elena Rybakina admitted that it was "quite unexpected" that so many top seeds have fallen around her at Wimbledon.

Aryna Sabalenka, who faces Emma Raducanu, is the only player in the top five remaining after exits for Coco Gauff, Jessica Pegula, Jasmine Paolini and Qinwen Zheng.

But Rybakina defeated Maria Sakkari in straight sets to reach the third round at SW19 for the fifth year in a row.

2022 Wimbledon champion Elena Rybakina breezes past Maria Sakkari and into round three.

She wins 6-3, 6-1 on Court One and will face the winner of Clara Tauson vs Anna Kalinskaya.

Next up on this court, Jack Draper! He faces Marin Cilic.

The provisional order of play (which could still change) has been announced for tomorrow.

Emma Raducanu will be the final match on Centre Court when she takes on world No.1 Aryna Sabalenka in the third round.

Centre Court (1.30pm) 

Fritz vs Davidovich Fokina

Struff vs Alcaraz

Sabalenka vs Raducanu

No 1 Court (1pm) 

Parry vs Kartal

Bellucci vs Norrie

Mertens vs Svitolina

No 2 (11am) 

Pavlyuchenkova vs Osaka

Siegmund vs Keys

Jarry vs Fonseca

Novak Djokovic was a picture of class after booking his spot in the third round with a win over Dan Evans, thanking the Centre Court crowd for a "special atmosphere".

He added: "A Brit in Britain is never easy to face. Dan Evans can be causing a lot of trouble if you are not on your game which I think I was from the beginning to be honest.

"I knew exactly what I needed to do and I executed it perfectly. Sometimes you have these kinds of days where everything goes your way."

The win was the Serb's 99th at Wimbledon, where he is a seven-time champion, and he added: "It means that I have been playing for quite a long time!

"I still enjoy and this sport has given me so much. Wimbledon still stays the most special tournament in my heart and the one that I always dreamed of winning when I was a kid.

"Any history made here is very special for me."



Dan Evans' Wimbledon run is over - he's suffered a 6-3 6-2 6-0 defeat to seven-time champion Novak Djokovic on Centre Court.

It was still a good week for Evans, who won his first main-draw singles match here since 2021. The former world No. 21 can take confidence from his impressive grass season, which saw him upset top-20 players Frances Tiafoe and Tommy Paul in Queen's and Eastbourne.

Carlos Alcaraz has become the latest tennis star to pay tribute after Diogo Jota and his brother Andre Silva passed away in a road traffic accident in Spain.

"Rest in peace Diogo and Andre. My sincere condolences to your loved ones," he wrote on Instagram.

It comes after Wimbledon bosses confirmed players would be allowed to wear a black ribbon to pay tribute to Jota.

British wildcard Arthur Fery's Wimbledon campaign has come to an end in the second round. He earned his first-ever tour-level win over 20th seed Alexei Popyrin in round one, causing a huge upset.

He trailed Italy's Luciano Darderi by two sets to love on Wednesday night when their match was suspended. And Darderi returned on Thursday to complete a 6-4 6-3 6-3 victory.

It's been a crazy start to Wimbledon for the top players, as 23 seeds went out across the men's and women's singles draws in the first round, and more continue to fall as the tournament progresses.

Reigning champion Carlos Alcaraz has benefited massively - it's now guaranteed that he could only face one seeded player until at least the semi-final.

The world No. 2 meets Jan-Lennard Struff in the third round.

No. 14 seed Andrey Rublev or French star Adrian Mannarino await in round four. And Nicolas Jarry, Joao Fonseca, Mattia Bellucci and Cameron Norrie are potential quarter-final opponents.

Novak Djokovic now leads Dan Evans by two sets on Centre Court 6-3 6-2.

No. 6 seed Mirra Andreeva is back into the third round at Wimbledon. The 18-year-old came back from a break down in the second set to beat Lucia Bronzetti 6-1 7-6(4) on Court 1.

Maria Sakkari takes on 2022 Wimbledon champion Elena Rybakina in the next match on the All England Club's second-biggest showcourt.



Plenty of big names have suffered upsets in the first two rounds of Wimbledon so far. But world No. 10 Emma Navarro made sure she wasn't one of them, sealing a dominant 6-2 6-2 win on Thursday.

The American was later asked why she thought there were so many shock early exits and said: "I'm not sure really. I feel like the grass is, I don't know, nothing wrong with the grass. Yeah, it was hot for a couple of days, but I think a lot of us are equipped to handle it, for sure.

"This time of year it's getting towards the second half of the season, and for a lot of players it's a lot of tournaments in a row, and it's a pretty long stint in Europe. Even if you go home for a couple of weeks, you kind of feel like you've been playing a lot.

"Wimbledon is sort of the end of a long few months in Europe. So maybe that has something to do with it. I'm not sure, but yeah, can't really tell you."

Novak Djokovic failed to convert his first nine break points in this second-round match. But he's finally taken his 10th, forcing an error from Dan Evans, and he's serving for the first set against the British wildcard on Centre Court.

Seven-time champion Djokovic easily serves out the first set to love 6-3.



Novak Djokovic is racing through his service games on Centre Court. But he's struggling on break points.

The Serb has had seven chances to break Dan Evans' serve and not taken any of them. It's 3-3 on Centre Court, and the fans are getting right behind the British wildcard.

Alex de Minaur is through to the third round after surviving an early wobble against qualifier Arthur Cazaux.

Plenty of top players have tumbled out of Wimbledon in the first few days, but the No. 11 seed made sure he wouldn't be one of them, storming back to win 4-6 6-2 6-4 6-0.

The All England Club has confirmed that it will make an exception to its all-white kit rule, allowing players to wear black ribbons to pay tribute to Diogo Jota and his brother Andre Silva, who passed away in a car accident.

To Centre Court, where Novak Djokovic faces Dan Evans.

The 24-time Major winner has just made a statement, winning the first game of the match in around one minute. He held to love and the longest rally was three shots.

But the fans are right behind Evans, a loud cheer erupted when he started his own service game with two aces.



Seven-time Wimbledon champion Novak Djokovic and British veteran Dan Evans have just stepped out onto Centre Court for their second-round clash.

Evans has an undefeated 1-0 record against Djokovic, upsetting the former No. 1 in Monte Carlo four years ago. But his ranking has taken a tumble over the last year, and he needed a wildcard to get into the main draw here.

"I think this is just a reward for Evans, he's had a difficult 12 months, he was up as high as No. 21 in the world," Tim Henman said on the BBC ahead of the match.

"He's shown his hunger and desire to try and drop down to the Challengers and build his way back up. Came through a comfortable victory against Jay Clarke and earned this opportunity to play Djokovic."

Former Wimbledon semi-finalist Hubert Hurkacz pulled out of the tournament last Friday, hours after the draw was made.

The ex-top-10 player has been battling injuries over the last year and has now announced that he's undergone knee surgery.

"After exploring different options, we decided that having an arthroscopy this past Monday was the best solution," he wrote."During the procedure, the overgrown synovial membrane causing the inflammation, pain, and related issues was removed. A huge thank you to Dr. Bartłomiej Kacprzak who performed the surgery."

A post shared by Hubert Hurkacz (@hubihurkacz)

Jack Pinnington Jones' Wimbledon run is officially over. The British wildcard earned a statement win over Tomas Etcheverry in the first round but he was no match for No. 22 seed Flavio Cobolli.

Pinnington Jones fought hard in the second set and looked on his way to taking it in the tiebreak. But the Italian shut the door and sealed a 6-1 7-6(6) 6-2 victory on Court 18.

He might have been facing a Brit, but Cobolli had plenty of supporters cheering and chanting his name on the outdoor court, which is open to grounds pass holders.



Well, that didn't take long in the end...

Alejandro Davidovich Fokina has finally booked his spot in the third round. The 26th seed led Botic van de Zandschulp blew a match point before play was suspended due to darkness at 5-5 in the fourth set last night.

But he's returned to seal victory on Court 6, spending less than half an hour on the court on Thursday to win 6-1 4-6 6-3 7-6(5). He let out a loud “vamos” and pointed towards the stands after taking it in a tiebreak.

Alejandro Davidovich Fokina is back out on Court 6 to resume his match against Botic van de Zandschulp after it was suspended due to darkness last night.

The Spanish 26th seed served for the match in the fourth set and got broken, then had a match point he couldn't take. Once van de Zandschulp levelled the score at 5-5, play was halted, and Davidovich Fokina wasn't happy.

Can he get the job done now? He's just held for a 6-5 lead.

British wildcard Jack Pinnington Jones put in an incredible effort in the second set of his match against 22nd seed Flavio Cobolli. The Italian served for it at 5-3 but got broken.

The world No. 281 forced a tiebreak and led by a mini-break but Cobolli has taken it 7-6(6)

There's work to do for Pinnington Jones - who is fresh out of college after opting not to return to Texas Christian University for his final year - if he wants to extend his time at Wimbledon. He's two sets down on Court 18.

Alex de Minaur is trying to avoid becoming the latest top seed to fall early.

The Aussie world No. 11 dropped the first set to qualifier Arthur Cazaux but he's just levelled the score 4-6 6-2.

No. 10 seed Emma Navarro became the first singles player to notch a win on Thursday as she stormed into the third round with a statement 6-1 6-2 victory over Veronika Kudermetova.

The American served for it at 5-0 in the second set and got broken. But she still raced through in an hour and 14 minutes. It'll be Grigor Dimitrov vs Corentin Moutet up next on Court 3.



Czech doubles duo Patrik Rikl and Petr Nouza were the first winners on day four of Wimbledon, upsetting No. 15 seeds and Olympic gold medallists Matt Ebden and John Peers 6-3 6-4 on Court 8.

The seeded players have been dropping like flies here at Wimbledon this week, with plenty of huge upsets across the first two rounds.

No. 11 seed Alex de Minaur is hoping to avoid being the latest victim - he's currently a set down to qualifier Arthur Cazaux on Court 2.

There's still a long way to go in this best-of-five set match, but the French world No. 115 leads 6-4.

Emma Raducanu took out 2023 Wimbledon champion Marketa Vondrousova 6-3 6-3 on Centre Court yesterday.

And former Olympic silver medallist Vondrousova - who beat Raducanu earlier this year in Abu Dhabi - was full of praise for the Brit's game.

“I think she was playing amazing tennis. Yeah, I couldn't do much. Like, I felt, you know, okay, but she was crushing me in the rallies, so there wasn't much I could do. I felt like it wasn't bad for my side, but yeah, she was better,” the Czech star said.

“I felt like here she was using a bit more, like, slices, and she was serving a bit differently than she did in Abu Dhabi. Yeah, I felt like, you know, like my slices and my game wasn't really working today. Yeah, all credit to her. I felt like she was playing some amazing tennis.”

British wildcard Jack Pinnington Jones is in trouble over on Court 18. No. 22 seed Flavio Cobolli has raced through the opening set 6-1 in 22 minutes.

Taylor Fritz played three days in a row at Wimbledon after his first-round match against Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard was suspended on Monday night ahead of the impending curfew.

He returned to win the fifth set on Tuesday. Then, last night, he beat Gabriel Diallo in five sets at around 10.20pm.

The No. 5 seed finally has a day off today and he's looking forward to sleeping in. But he can't prepare for his next match just yet as he plays the winner of a clash between ALejandro Davidovich Fokina and Botic van de Zandschulp which was suspended on Wednesday night and will continue today.

Fritz said: "I mean, I think it will be a light practice, for sure. I'm going to sleep in late, have a practice around, I don't know, like 2 or 3. Probably won't hit more than 30 minutes, I think.

"Hitting-wise, there's no need really. I think the biggest thing is I'm going to have to work on some returns because... I mean, I guess it depends. I don't know who I play yet."

Retired former world No. 1 Rafael Nadal has become the latest tennis player to pay tribute after Diogo Jota and his brother Andre passed away in a road traffic accident.

The Spaniard tweeted: "What terribly sad and painful news. All my love, affection, and support to his wife, his children, his family, and his friends in such a difficult moment. Rest in Peace, Diogo Jota and Andre Silva."

Emma Raducanu takes on world No. 1 Aryna Sabalenka in the third round here tomorrow. Raducanu lost their only previous match in Indian Wells last year. But after the Brit took out 2023 Marketa Vondrousova on Wednesday, Annabel Croft believes Raducanu could have a chance against a vulnerable Sabalenka.

“I felt like Sabalenka struggled a little bit in her first set yesterday. She very nearly dropped the first set, so she's not 100 per cent. There's a lot of interest in that match. I'm looking forward to it,” she said on the BBC.

It's just gone 11am and play is getting underway on the outside courts at the All England Club.

No. 11 seed Alex de Minaur faces qualifier Arthur Cazaux on Court 2, while No. 10 seed Emma Navarro faces Veronika Kudermetova.

There's British interest as wilcard Jack Pinnington Jones is starting play on Court 18 against No. 22 seed Flavio Cobolli.

And the first round of the doubles continues today.

British former doubles No. 1 Neal Skupski has paid tribute after Diogo Jota and his brother passed away in a road traffic accident.

Ahead of his first-round match at Wimbledon today, Skupski tweeted: "Tragic news. YNWA"

British No. 2 Katie Boulter suffered a disappointing three-set defeat to lucky loser Solana Sierra on Wednesday.

Boulter has still never reached the second week of a Grand Slam tournament despite being a former world No. 23 and winning three singles titles.

After her 6-7 6-2 6-1 defeat she admitted it may never happen.

"It's a really tough pill to swallow. It always is here. Unfortunately it's just the way that it is. Sometimes I just have to accept that my moment might not come at some point," a dejected Boulter said.

Jack Draper is the talk of the town at Wimbledon this fortnight. Ranked at No. 4 in the world, he is arguably Britain's biggest hope to win the men's singles title here since Andy Murray.

But another British Jack has been causing a stir at SW19. Jack Pinnington Jones got a wildcard into the main draw and faces 22nd seed Flavio Cobolli on Thursday.

Pinnington Jones goes way back with Draper, revealing that the British No. 1 used to drive him to practice at the National Tennis Centre.

"He can't sit in traffic, or he'd hate to sit in traffic so Jack would say: ‘Right, I'm going to be there at 6:30. You're either there or you're not'. I'd be half asleep every time. And I'd be there at 7am with nothing to do," Pinnington Jones said of their journeys together.

Taylor Fritz found himself dragged into another five-setter at Wimbledon.

On Monday night, his first-round match against Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard was halted before the fifth and final set could start. It was 10.15pm - 45 minutes before curfew - and Fritz wanted to play on but the supervisor told them to return the following day. He came back to win, then beat Gabriel Diallo in five sets on Wednesday evening.

Luckily for Fritz, they were able to finish the match in one night. After avoiding more curfew drama, he said: "I would have lost my mind if they tried to get us at, like, 9:50pm.

"There was plenty of time. I would have absolutely lost it because then I would have had to play again and then again. I need a day off at some point."



Jannik Sinner's coach Darren Cahill has revealed the Italian cheated on his diet after losing the French Open final to Carlos Alcaraz.

"We had this big bus where we all sit in and for the players they have this candy jar that you can take a couple of candies as you walk out," said Cahill on ESPN.

"He took the whole jar. He grabbed the glass jar, had the candies, he'd been on a strict diet for two weeks and that was it. The diet was out the window.

"In the car, he was handing candies out to everyone. He was laughing, he was giggling.

"He moved on pretty quickly and it'll be interesting to see how he moves on here because this will be the big test."

Naomi Osaka has admitted to experiencing a greater degree of 'fear' than she did in her younger days.

The four-time Grand Slam champion opened up in an honest press conference after beating Katerina Siniakova yesterday.

"When I was younger, I had no fear and I think when you're young you fear nothing and that's one of the really cool things about it," said Osaka.

"But I don't know, with age fear kind of crept along and I guess paralyzed me in a way so now I'm kind of just getting over that and trying to spread my wings on grass.

"Ithink it is working and I think I am moving pretty well and yeah, I just hope that in years to come and hopefully this year I can do a lot better in this tournament."

Fans heading to Wimbledon might be able to find some genuine match kit in the local charity shops.

That is because Joe Salisbury has been donating his competition shirts and clothing for the last 'four or five years'.

The four-time Grand Slam doubles champion told Express Sport: "Obviously, we have different match kits throughout the year.

"I think we get maybe even five, six, different ones. And we usually get given quite a lot of stuff from our sponsors.

"Once you've used one of them and you're onto to the next one, then you've got a lot of stuff left over.

"I usually give some to friends and family and then a lot of still got lots more of the old stuff, so then I give the rest of that to the charity shop."



All eyes will be on Centre Court later when Dan Evans takes on Novak Djokovic for a place in the third round.

The pair have only faced off once in their careers, with the Brit surprisingly coming out on top 6-4 7-4 at the Monte Carlo Masters four years ago.

But the Brit once took Djokovic to task over his comments on events being played during the Covid pandemic...

Here's a look at what's coming up on the main courts at Wimbledon today...

Centre Court (from 1.30pm)

Dan Evans vs Novak Djokovic

Iga Swiatek vs Caty McNally

Jannik Sinner vs Aleksandar Vukic

Court One (from 1pm)

Mirra Andreeva vs Lucia Bronzetti

Maria Sakkari vs Elena Rybakina

Jack Draper vs Marin Cilic

The full schedule can be found on the Wimbledon website.

Oliver Tarvet earned £99,000 for reaching the second round but will be forced to give most of it away.

He attends university in the United States and the rules of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) require athletes to stay amateur.

Tarvet is able to claim up to £7,282 in expenses as well as the expenses he has incurred during the tournament.

However, he will miss out on the vast majority of his Wimbledon payout, which will go to his university.

Fellow tennis prodigy Benjamin Heynold continued to fuel rumours of a romance with Emma Raducanu on Wednesday.

He was in her box to watch her beat Marketa Vondrousova and reach the third round at SW19.

It comes just a day after he appeared in the background of a selfie Raducanu had taken.

There was talk of a potential romance after Heynold was spotted in her team's corner at Queen's Club last month.



Hello and welcome to Express Sport's live coverage of Wimbledon on day four of the tournament.

We'll be bringing you the latest updates from SW19 throughout the day, so grab a coffee and stay tuned...

Title: Wimbledon 2025 live: Raducanu storms past Vondrousova after Alcaraz beats spirited Brit Tarvet
Description:
Notifications can be managed in browser preferences.

Please refresh the page or navigate to another page on the site to be automatically logged inPlease refresh your browser to be logged in

Follow live updates and scores from day four of the Wimbledon Championships at the All England Club

It's day four of Wimbledon 2025 and it's another packed schedule ahead with Novak Djokovic, Iga Swiatek, Jack Draper and Jannik Sinner all in action. 

To the dismay of the home crowd, Djokovic thrashed Britain's Dan Evans in Centre Court's opening match, as the seven-time Wimbledon champion recorded his 99th win at the grass-court slam. That match came after Evans's young teammate Jack Pinnington Jones was beaten by 22nd seed Flavio Cobolli. 

There is still hope for the home crop, though: last out on No 1 Court, Draper faces former major winner and Wimbledon finalist Marin Cilic. 

Yesterday saw impressive wins by Emma Raducanu and Sonay Kartal in the second round of the ladies' draw, although their fellow Briton Katie Boulter bowed out. Raducanu will play the world No 1 Aryna Sabalenka in a highly anticipated contest on Friday. On the men's side, Cameron Norrie knocked out 12th seed Frances Tiafoe to book his spot in the third round, while Carlos Alcaraz saw off the spirited efforts of British qualifier Ollie Tarvet.

Follow all the latest scores and results from Wimbledon below. 

Jack Draper has had a lot to contemplate so far in this match

The old tennis cliche of a break not being worth a damn until it's consolidated with a hold of serve feels very apt here.

Pressure on Draper as he squanders game point, allowing Cilic to force deuce. But a couple of big serves bail him out. That was a very, very important hold. The set is at his mercy now.

Well, well, well. What have we here? Draper gets himself to 0-30 and then a Cilic forehand is netted. 

Three break points for Draper, having had just two in the entire match so far. First one SAVED by Cilic, who holds a hand up in apology as a net cord goes his way. Draper chuntering away to himself/the tennis Gods in response...

Second one SAVED. Big serve, unreturned. Surely Draper can't afford to squander all three? He doesn't! Well-constructed point and a forehand down the line secures the break for Jack Draper. Big! Can that be a turning point?

Draper's serve is finding its range more consistently now, although his service games are still peppered with moments of Cilic brilliance, such as his thumping forehand winner here.

But in the end, a fairly simple hold to 15 for the Brit.

If you're a Jack Draper fan and looking for the smallest, and I do mean smallest, of consolations, at least he's serving first in this third set.

If his serve holds up as it's going to need to to entertain any sort of epic, late-night, Andy Murray-esque comeback, then he'll have the edge of being ahead and pressurising the Cilic serve.

Draper breezes through his first service game to lay the early template but Cilic responds with a hold to love. Fist pump and an intense look in the eyes of the big Croatian.

Swiatek 5-7, 6-2, 6-1 McNally

You know what, that's a good win all told in the end for Iga Swiatek.

Having dropped the first set from being ahead, she hit back to race through the final two sets against Caty McNally, claiming the decider 6-1.

I know she's not the most comfortable on grass but the way the women's draw is opening up, Swiatek might like her chances of going deep

A “come on” from draper to pump himself up as he wins the first point to get an early foothold in the Cilic service game but that's great power! Cilic just unfurls himself to arrow a backhand winner cross-court before an ace down the ‘T'. 

Unreturned serve and it's two set points. Smooth as you like! Draper's return goes long and Marin Cilic has won the second set 6-3. He's just one set away from a big upset on No 1 Court. Draper in all sorts of trouble

The Draper serve is starting, slowly but surely, to solidify as he bangs down a couple of unreturned serves and finds a clean forehand winner.

Cilic still has a sniff at 40-30 but the Brit sees it out. The Croat will serve for a two-set lead here though.

Cilic loves a long ball bounce before each serve but he's in a rhythm here.

The 36-year-old veteran is absolutely rolling back the years. Draper floats a groundstroke long on the first point of the game but after that it's all Cilic's brilliance.

Two impressive aces sandwiched by a point where he finds a crunching cross-court forehand winner. Sublime

Alarm bells ringing again for the Brit when he slips 0-15 down but responds well to string a few points together and win the game for a vital hold of serve.

Can he put any sort of pressure on the Cilic serve though?

Join thought-provoking conversations, follow other Independent readers and see their replies

Title: Raducanu shows glimpses of best form in beating former Wimbledon champion Vondrousova
Description:
Emma Raducanu played some of her best tennis since her U.S. Open title run in 2021 by sweeping aside former Wimbledon champion Marketa Vondrousova 6-3, 6-3 and reach the third round

LONDON — Emma Raducanu played some of her most clinical tennis since her U.S. Open title run to sweep aside 2023 Wimbledon champion Marketa Vondrousova 6-3, 6-3 on Wednesday and reach the third round.

In front of a raucous Centre Court crowd, Raducanu surprised even herself sometimes in outdueling the Czech player in a match between Grand Slam winners who were both unseeded.

“That was one of the best matches I've played in a long time,” said Raducanu, the 2021 champion at Flushing Meadows . “I turned one point around that I think is probably the best point I've ever played, so that was pretty crazy. I think the crowd were loving it.”

She may have to up her level even further in the next match, though. In a tournament where four of the five top women's seeds have already been eliminated, the British home favorite will be up against the only one remaining — No. 1 Aryna Sabalenka .

“Yeah, I guess there's no pressure at all on me the next round,” Raducanu said in an on-court interview, laughing.

There's always pressure on Raducanu playing at Wimbledon, especially after she became the first British woman since 1977 to capture a Grand Slam title when she won the U.S. Open as a qualifier.

She struggled with injuries and form after that, and her fourth-round showing at Wimbledon last year is her best result in a major since.

But her win against Vondrousova, who in 2019 was the French Open runner-up, showed Raducanu might be back to her best.

“She was playing amazing tennis,” Vondrousova said. “She was crushing me in the rallies, so there wasn't much I could do.”

Raducanu seemed pretty impressed with her own performance as well.

“I think today I played really, really well,” she said. “I knew today I had to be aggressive because Marketa would beat me if I was going to push the ball around.”

___

More AP tennis: https://apnews.com/hub/tennis

Title: Wimbledon power couple 'break up' and facing extremely awkward U.S. Open situation
Description:
Tennis's beloved "Tsitsidosa" has parted ways. Paula Badosa and Stefános Tsitsipas, romantically linked since 2023 and briefly reconciled in 2024, have quietly ended their relationship for a second time, according to reports in Spain.

The split reportedly ignited after both were ousted in the first round at Wimbledon — Badosa losing to Katie Boulter, and Tsitsipas withdrawing mid-match due to a persistent back injury. Soon after, they unfollowed each other on Instagram and removed all traces of their romance. It comes after Badosa admitted she is facing early retirement in a heartbreaking admission, while Tsitsipas offerde a bleak outlook on his own Wimbledon pain.

According to Spanish celebrity magazine Hola, sources close to the couple described the breakup as “mature and amicable,” without third-party interference, but emphasize that lingering professional pressures and recurring injuries played a major role. This separation poses an awkward situation as they were expected to reunite on court as mixed doubles partners at the upcoming U.S. Open — a joyful pairing that was publicized in late June.

Organizers had already announced their entry as a wildcard team, generating excitement among fans. With the reported split, their U.S. Open involvement is now clouded with uncertainty and potential awkwardness, both personally and in the press.

The Wimbledon exit seems to have functioned as the final straw. Badosa and Tsitsipás had previously broken up in May 2024, but swiftly reconciled soon after. This time, sources suggest, the toll of injuries and disappointing tournament results proved too great.

Both players have been navigating difficult career stretches: Badosa, once ranked No. 2, has fallen after an injury-riddled season and an early Wimbledon exit.

Similarly, Tsitsipas, once a top-5 player, now copes with a nagging back issue threatening his season. It's now clear these professional challenges intertwined with their personal lives, ultimately fracturing the bond they once cemented.

Despite removing each other from social media and withdrawing public displays of affection, there's no animosity involved. According to insiders, both express mutual respect and love, citing the breakup as “healthy” and “adult.” They emphasized no infidelity or family interference — just two individuals facing mounting pressures.

As the U.S. Open approaches — with its Grand Slam spotlight and mixed doubles bracket already publicized — their breakup sets the stage for a potentially tense reunion. Will they still share the court? Will they withdraw quietly, or risk headlines by playing side by side? Tournament organizers and fans alike are watching closely.

Title: Ben Shelton Clarifies His Feelings About US Open After Hilarious Slip-Up at Wimbledon
Description:
Ben Shelton had the crowd in stitches during his opening-round victory at Wimbledon after a lighthearted slip-up about his favorite Grand Slam. The 22-year-old American quickly clarified his allegiance, jokingly reassuring supporters that the US Open still holds a special place in his heart, where he reached the semifinals in 2023.

Shelton, the No. 10 seed at the 2025 Championships, cruised past Australian qualifier Alex Bolt in straight sets, 6-4, 7-6(1), 7-6(4). Known for his booming serve, Shelton landed 15 aces and won 82% of his first-serve points to seal the win. But a moment during his on-court interview drew loud laughter from the Wimbledon crowd.

“I love playing at the Grand Slams. It's one of my four favorite tournaments here,” Shelton quipped, pausing as the audience erupted in laughter. Realizing his gaffe, he grinned and added, “I can't do my home slam that dirty, but one of my favorites, 100%. I love playing here every year.”

 

 

A post shared by Wimbledon (@wimbledon)



The official Wimbledon Instagram account posted the humorous exchange shortly after the match. Shelton couldn't resist chiming in himself, responding, “Sorry, NYC always comes first.”

Shelton first appeared in the US Open main draw in 2022, where he suffered a first-round exit after losing to Nuno Borges. He enjoyed a breakthrough run at Flushing Meadows in 2023, defeating Pedro Cachin, Dominic Thiem, Aslan Karatsev, and fellow Americans Tommy Paul and Frances Tiafoe to advance to the semifinals. There, he lost in straight sets to eventual champion Novak Djokovic. In 2024, his campaign ended in the third round with a loss to Tiafoe.

Shelton now moves on to face another Australian, Rinky Hijikata, in the second round at SW19. This will be their second meeting on the ATP Tour, with Shelton winning their first clash at the 2024 Mallorca Championships. They previously faced each other twice on the Challenger circuit, splitting the matches with one win apiece.

The winner of this match will take on either lucky loser Márton Fucsovics or Gaël Monfils in the third round.

Shelton made his Wimbledon debut in 2023, where he defeated Taro Daniel to reach the second round, eventually losing 6-3, 3-6, 6-7(5), 3-6 to Laslo Djere. The following year, he cruised past Mattia Bellucci, Lloyd Harris, and Denis Shapovalov to reach the fourth round, where he lost 2-6, 4-6, 6-7(9) to Jannik Sinner.

MORE: Jimmy Connors Predicts Who Among Americans Ben Shelton, Taylor Fritz, Tommy Paul Would Enjoy Success at Wimbledon 2025

Title: Wimbledon star who defeated Andy Murray once lived on $200 and instant noodles
Description:
Taro Daniel has opened up about the monetary challenges faced by players ranked outside the world's top 100. Most recognized for defeating Andy Murray in the second round of the Australian Open three years ago, Daniel was among numerous contenders who couldn't advance through Wimbledon's qualifying stages.

Despite his determined effort, the 32 year old was eliminated in the second qualifying round, falling 6-4, 4-6, 6-4 to France's Titouan Droguet. Speaking about his financial concerns, Daniel has been compelled to manage his income carefully due to steep expenses related to travel, coaching and physiotherapy.

Following his $200,000 earnings for reaching the third round in Melbourne, the tennis professional endured years of weekly losses, forced to give up personal luxuries to preserve funds.

"In 2017, after an early exit at the French Open, I had $200 in my account," he confessed. "I survived on instant noodles and skipped tournaments because I couldn't afford flights.

"When I was younger, I even wouldn't get the avocado on my Chipotle order because it's like three dollars more. When you try to save too much it ends up impacting people's games negatively."

From the beginning of 2025, Daniel has earned slightly more than $185,000 in prize money. Nevertheless, multiple expenditures have substantially diminished that sum, leaving him with a substantial credit card balance monthly to handle necessary expenses.

"First of all, you're earning all of this money from foreign countries so they're going to take all the withholding taxes," Daniel explained. "Tournaments cover your hotel room, but they don't cover your coach's hotel room.

"My credit card statement, it's at least $20,000 a month on just operational expenses of hotel, food, flights and not including the salaries I pay to my team.

"As a tennis player, you're like a small company but having all your employees travelling all the time. [It's] at least $100,000 per season for your basic level, not super experienced coach.

"10 years ago, when I started, a lot of players would travel alone because the standards were not as high. Now, it would be very rare for someone to travel alone to a Grand Slam, for example.

"Everyone has a coach or trainer. They're probably right on the red-black line. Even in a Slam, you're not necessarily making money."

Daniel had his sights set on a hefty prize pot at Wimbledon, where first-round contenders pocket $90,000, second-round participants earn £99,000, and advancing to the third round means raking in $207,000.

The champion of the entire tournament is set to bag an eye-watering $4 million – a record-breaking amount for a Grand Slam event.

Yet, the Japanese star faces several more challenging months before he can lay claim to any game-changing prize money.

Title: Jim Courier names the Grand Slam winner Petra Kvitova reminded him of as she loses her final match at Wimbledon
Description:
Petra Kvitova enjoyed a legendary tennis career, winning two Grand Slam titles and the WTA Finals.

The Czech legend won her first Grand Slam at Wimbledon in 2011, defeating Russia's Maria Sharapova in the final.

Three years later, Kvitova won Wimbledon for a second time, when she took down Eugenie Bouchard in straight sets.

Now aged 35, Kvitova is set to retire from tennis in 2025, and was competing at Wimbledon one final time.

Unfortunately for the former world number two, she couldn't secure the win in her opening match as she lost to Emma Navarro 3-6, 1-6.

Reflecting on Kvitova's stellar career, Jim Courier named the major winner whom she reminded him of.

Appearing on the Tennis Channel, Courier compared Kvitova to another Czech tennis legend.

“It must not have been too lovely to be on the other side of the net when she was at her apex, this is one of the sweetest strikers of a tennis ball that you will see, especially on fast courts, just beautiful timing,” he said.

“Reminds me of her fellow Czech, Petr Korda, back in our time on tour, when he was in the zone, he was unplayable.

“I feel that way about Kvitova, a lefty like Petr, just elegant on the court and off the court.

“We will miss her, but she has a lot to look forward to with her family life, of course.”

Lindsay Davenport was keen to weigh in with her thoughts as she spoke highly of the two-time Wimbledon champion.

“She's so well-liked off the court. Never upset anyone; everyone loves her. It was great to follow her and her career,” she said.

Courier said Kvitova reminded him of Korda, a Grand Slam champion in his own right.

Korda contested two singles Grand Slam finals in his career, at the French Open in 1992 and at the Australian Open in 1996.

Losing his first to Courier at Roland Garros, the Czech was determined to emerge victorious the second time around.

Travelling to Melbourne as the number six seed in 1996, Korda battled his way through to the final, where he took on Chile's Marcelo Rios.

Winning in straight sets, Korda dominated Rios 6-2, 6-2, 6-2, to clinch his sole major title.

He returned to Melbourne just once more in 1999, losing in the third round to Todd Martin before retiring from tennis shortly after when he received a 12-month doping ban.

During her post-match press conference, Kvitova gave her verdict on the tournament, which she won in 2011 and 2014.

“Wimbledon was the main thing that shaped me throughout my career, as a person as well. I do get along very nicely with the English people, with their sense of humour as well, I love it,” she said.

“I think it was the main thing which happened to me in my life, from nobody, I was somebody.”

Looking back at the second of her two Wimbledon wins, Kvitova believes she proved herself at the ‘best tournament in the world'.

“I was struggling a little bit as well, but the second title was the best as well, that was something that was satisfying, proving that I could play well and that I was a good player,” she said.

“Even though I was in the top ten for a pretty long time, the Grand Slams are the biggest trophies that you can have, and to have two, especially Wimbledon, is something very special and an honor to have.

“I think it's the best tournament in the world.”

Kvitova will retire as one of just three players, alongside Serena and Venus Williams, to have won multiple Wimbledon titles this century, esteemed company for the Czech legend.

Title: ‘Sounds different': Why Aussie hopeful, Wimbledon should fear Jannik Sinner after ‘best ever' build-up
Description:
Smack. Boom. Thhwaaack! A sound like a whip cracking echoed repeatedly across the practice courts at Wimbledon on Wednesday. 

The skies were heavy over the All England Lawn Tennis Club but the thunderclaps being unleashed shortly after midday had nothing to do with the weather, though they most certainly would have alarmed Aussie hopeful Aleks Vukic had he been within earshot.

Out on the Aorangi practice courts which adjoin Wimbledon, Jannik Sinner was inflicting a grievous assault on the set of tennis balls he was pummelling. And “The Sinner Spectacle” on Court 4 was compelling viewing.

Watch the biggest Aussie sports & the best from overseas LIVE on Kayo Sports | New to Kayo? Get your first month for just $1. Limited time offer.



The sound that comes from the racquet of the world No.1, who plays Vukic on Thursday on Centre Court, is distinct to most players, with the starkness amplified at Aorangi given the fact several players were practising on courts laid side-by-side at the same time. 

Alongside was Amanda Anisimova, a highly talented American who double-bagelled Yulia Putintseva in the first round. Going through her paces on Court 3, the No.13 seed struck the ball sweetly, but the pace of her shots was pedestrian compared to the Italian. 

When Sinner unleashes with his forehand, it sounds like a pistol has been fired. And he was murdering the ball in a session that drew several interested onlookers.

READ MORE

‘THAT'S F***ING TICKER': The moment Aussie answered Lleyton's call as freak Wimbledon streak rolls on



WRAP: World No.733 wins the hearts of Wimbledon; shock exit in latest victim of giant killings 





As his compatriot Andrea Vavassori said in Miami last year; “For sure you could see when you heard the sound of the ball, the explosion, I think you could understand that he was different from others. The sound when he plays forehands and backhands is different from the other players.”

As this journalist watched the dual-Australian Open champion in action, last year's Wimbledon and Roland Garros finalist Jasmine Paolini edged in to the row alongside to witness Sinner work his younger practice partner over. 

Protecting herself from the chill that descended on Wednesday with a cream-coloured hoodie after the scorching days to open Wimbledon, she seemed as fascinated as everyone else watching her compatriot blast balls into oblivion.

The attraction is scarcely a surprise. After all, had Sinner managed to seize one of three match points in the phenomenal French Open final against Carlos Alcaraz last month, the tennis world would be pondering whether he could complete the “Sinner slam” this fortnight.



As superb as the broadcasting of live sport is, the cameras never truly depict just how hard tennis players hit the ball, nor how swiftly they move, the extent of the contortions of their bodies or, to emphasise the point again, the sound of the ball off the racquet.

The weight and depth of his groundstrokes were formidable, with the 23-year-old leathering the ball crosscourt with his hitting partner, who was wearing a sleeve on his right arm, before unleashing lethal forehands down the line. Boom! Another ball destroyed.

About 40 minutes in Sinner changed from a white T-shirt into a red one and began pounding serves. The pace through the air and the movement off the court, be it arcing away with a slice or kicking like a mule to the right on landing, is alarming to behold, let alone face.

Watching Sinner on Wednesday, as others including Australian Davis Cup captain Lleyton Hewitt and his deputy Jaymon Crabb were from a side-on vantage point, it was impossible to imagine anyone beating him. Yet that is the task confronting Vukic on Thursday.

Asked if would have to serve exceptionally well to stay with Sinner, who won both their outings in convincing fashion while he was still a teenager, the Australian Davis Cup representative responded; “Yeah. And probably more.”

“I'll have to take my chances and have to play a very good match. But I've got nothing to lose,” Vukic said.

While Sinner looked unbeatable in practice, he has lost twice in the past month. Aside from the epic against Alcaraz at Roland Garros, Alexander Bublik defeated him in three sets in Halle in his first match after the heartbreaker.

Nor is it uncommon for even the best players to suffer a lull after an excruciating loss. Alexander Zverev, who was bounced from Wimbledon on Tuesday, is a case in point. The German has not been the same player since falling to Sinner in the Australian Open final.





But Sinner's co-coach Darren Cahill, who was wearing a white jumper and green tracksuit pants while supervising the spectacle on Wednesday, told American television prior to Wimbledon that the Italian had bounced back quickly from the Paris heartbreaker.

The Australian master coach revealed a break in diet and a small act of rebellion as he left the Roland Garros locker room was Sinner's first step in the recovery process.

“For the players, they have this candy jar, where you can take a couple of candies when you walk out of Roland Garros. But he took the whole jar,” Cahill said.

“He had been on a strict diet for two weeks and that was it. The diet was out the window. He was handing candies out to everyone. He was giggling. He was laughing. He moved on pretty quickly. But it will be interesting to see how he moves on here, because this will be the big test.”





Sinner, who was a semi-finalist at Wimbledon in 2023 and has a 14-4 record at the AELTC, became sharper as his opening round match against compatriot Luca Nardi whistled by 6-4 6-3 6-0, which is not a surprise given Cahill's pre-tournament assessment.

“He has had the best week of practice on grass that he has ever had. He is rejuvenated. He is fresh mentally. He looks good,” Cahill said.

“The first couple of matches will be interesting. He has to get his teeth into the tournament and I think if he can get through the first couple of matches, he will be completely fine. 

“The fact is also that had he won (Roland Garros), we would be competing here for the ‘Sinner slam'. He would have won three in a row. So he knows he is around the mark. He is improving all the time on grass. Mentally, he has great self awareness and great perspective on where he is in the game and what he has done to get himself into this position.”





It is an important moment for Vukic, who is in action alongside fellow Australians Alex de Minaur, Rinky Hijikata and Daria Kasatkina.

Last year the popular Sydneysider faced Alcaraz on Court 1 in the second round and stretched the Spanish superstar for a set. Now the No.93 gets an opportunity to play the world's best on the most famous court in tennis.

“I remember last year going out onto the court for the first time (and) it was a little bit surreal,” he said.

“But, and I was talking to coach about this, it is also a little bit more peaceful at the same time, because actually (the outside courts are) quite chaotic, with a lot going on around. You hear all the voices around, whereas over there (on the show courts) you kind of get left alone a little bit. It's actually ... sometimes less distracting to be out there. So it is different.”

No matter what unfolds on Thursday afternoon, Vukic will be able to tell his grandkids about the day he played the world No.1 on a Wimbledon Centre Court card that also featured 24-time major winner Novak Djokovic and four-time French Open star Iga Swiatek.

And that is pretty cool.

Title: Fonseca: No. 1 dreams, Federer-Nadal fandom & more
Description:
Joao Fonseca closed his eyes in relief and put his head in his hands on Wednesday. The Brazilian had just booked his place in the Wimbledon third round, equalling his best result at a major. The 18-year-old, who won last year's Next Gen ATP Finals presented by PIF, will next meet Nicolas Jarry in a South American clash on the SW19 grass.

ATPTour.com caught up with Fonseca earlier this year to learn about his journey. The teenager shared his greatest success, favourite rivalry, favourite tournament and more.



What has been your greatest success?
Well, my greatest success has been winning the Next Gen [Next Gen ATP Finals presented by PIF] or maybe winning my first title, the ATP 250 in Buenos Aires.

What's been the most unique moment in your career?
The most unique moment in my career was winning against [Cristian] Garin in the round of 16 at the Rio Open, the ATP 500 which is in my hometown. And for me it was super unique.

What is the biggest number or the accomplishment that you're chasing?
My biggest dream is to become No. 1 in the world, so I'm working very hard to one day get it.

How long have you been pursuing that dream?
For a long time, since I was 10 years old. 

What is your favourite ATP tournament to play?
My favourite ATP tournament to play is the Rio Open, which is my home. Playing [in front of] my friends, family, and the Brazilian crowd is super amazing for me.







What's been the coolest off-court experience you've had as a professional tennis player?
The coolest off-court experience that I had was to get in a boat on the Red Sea in Jeddah when I went to the Next Gen [ATP Finals presented by PIF].
What made it so cool?
I was with the seven best under-20 guys. So, it was super cool. It was a super nice experience. First time in the Red Sea, and just enjoying a great boat. It was really cool with the guys.
What is your favourite tennis rivalry?
I [will] say Rafa and Federer. I mean Federer is my idol. What they both achieved, I love watching them both play long matches. It's super good to see those guys. 
Who is your greatest rival?
I'm still young, so there's no one that I played [enough]. There's one guy, when I was 14, Pedro Rodrigues — Brazilian player — but he's in college now. He plays some ITFs, and now he's in college. But that was one guy, we had a good, good rivalry. It was always a difficult match.

Title: Zeynep Sonmez becomes first Turkish player to reach third round of a Grand Slam in Open Era
Description:
The 23-year-old took out recent Berlin finalist Wang Xinyu on Thursday to make history for her country.ByTENNIS.comPublished Jul 03, 2025 copy_link

Published Jul 03, 2025

Zeynep Sonmez has made history, becoming the first Turkish player in the Open Era to reach the third round of a Grand Slam.She achieved the feat at Wimbledon on Thursday with a 7-5, 7-5 victory over China's Wang Xinyu in the second round of the grass-court major, battling back from 4-1 down to win the first set and then serving to stay in the second set at 4-5 before breaking for 6-5 and serving it out in the next game.She had beaten Romania's Jaqueline Cristian in the first round, 7-6 (3), 6-3, for her first career win in the main draw of a major.Wang had recently reached the final at one of the biggest warm-up events to Wimbledon, in Berlin, and—at No. 32—was one of the first few players out of the seeds. She had beaten the No. 15 seed, Karolina Muchova, in the first round.Sonmez is playing in the main draw of Wimbledon for the first time.

She achieved the feat at Wimbledon on Thursday with a 7-5, 7-5 victory over China's Wang Xinyu in the second round of the grass-court major, battling back from 4-1 down to win the first set and then serving to stay in the second set at 4-5 before breaking for 6-5 and serving it out in the next game.She had beaten Romania's Jaqueline Cristian in the first round, 7-6 (3), 6-3, for her first career win in the main draw of a major.Wang had recently reached the final at one of the biggest warm-up events to Wimbledon, in Berlin, and—at No. 32—was one of the first few players out of the seeds. She had beaten the No. 15 seed, Karolina Muchova, in the first round.Sonmez is playing in the main draw of Wimbledon for the first time.

Wang had recently reached the final at one of the biggest warm-up events to Wimbledon, in Berlin, and—at No. 32—was one of the first few players out of the seeds. She had beaten the No. 15 seed, Karolina Muchova, in the first round.Sonmez is playing in the main draw of Wimbledon for the first time.

Sonmez is playing in the main draw of Wimbledon for the first time.

Sonmez won her first WTA title and broke into the Top 100 for the first time last November.© Afp or licensors

© Afp or licensors

This isn't the first time Sonmez has made headlines for Turkey.The 23-year-old made a surprise run to the first WTA title of her career last November, in Merida, Mexico. With that, she became just the second Turkish player ever to win a WTA title, after Cagla Buyukakcay, who won on home soil in Istanbul in 2016.Sonmez subsequently broke into the Top 100 for the first time, becoming the second Turkish player ever to reach the Top 100 on the WTA rankings, after, again, Buyukakcay.Buyukakcay has reached the second round at Grand Slams three times, at Roland Garros and the US Open in 2016, then Roland Garros again in 2017.Awaiting Sonmez in the third round of Wimbledon on Saturday will be the winner of No. 18 seed Ekaterina Alexandrova and the Netherlands' Suzan Lamens.

Title: Hall of Fame Open to feature highest purse at WTA 125 level
Description:
Women's professional tennis will return to the International Tennis Hall of Fame next week for the first time since the 1990s.ByAssociated PressPublished Jul 03, 2025 copy_link

Published Jul 03, 2025

© 2023 Getty Images

NEWPORT, R.I. (AP) — Women's professional tennis returns to the International Tennis Hall of Fame next week with the highest purse at the WTA 125 level.Both the men's and women's tours will have tournaments at the Hall of Fame Open, with both the women's event and the ATP Challenger one featuring $200,000 purses.While the ATP Tour had continued with the post-Wimbledon event on the Hall's grass courts, the women's tour hadn't played there since the 1990s.Read More: Tennis Hall of Fame getting a face lift in time for golden era inductees Roger Federer & Serena WilliamsIn order to return with equal prize money, the tournament partnered with the MARGARET ("May All Resolve, Girls Achieve Real Equity Today") Fund, which supports programs that promote education about and compliance with Title IX. That allowed for a 60 percent increase in the women's tour purse to match the men's at the event.

Both the men's and women's tours will have tournaments at the Hall of Fame Open, with both the women's event and the ATP Challenger one featuring $200,000 purses.While the ATP Tour had continued with the post-Wimbledon event on the Hall's grass courts, the women's tour hadn't played there since the 1990s.Read More: Tennis Hall of Fame getting a face lift in time for golden era inductees Roger Federer & Serena WilliamsIn order to return with equal prize money, the tournament partnered with the MARGARET ("May All Resolve, Girls Achieve Real Equity Today") Fund, which supports programs that promote education about and compliance with Title IX. That allowed for a 60 percent increase in the women's tour purse to match the men's at the event.

In order to return with equal prize money, the tournament partnered with the MARGARET ("May All Resolve, Girls Achieve Real Equity Today") Fund, which supports programs that promote education about and compliance with Title IX. That allowed for a 60 percent increase in the women's tour purse to match the men's at the event.

The Hall of Fame Open begins with qualifying on Sunday and runs through July 13.Americans Alycia Parks, Hailey Baptiste, Jenson Brooksby and Christopher Eubanks highlight the women's and men's player field entries, which also features Tatjana Maria, Adrian Mannarino, Heather Watson, and more.“This year's Hall of Fame Open boasts an exceptional player field, featuring Grand Slam contenders, title winners so far this year and stars on the rise,” said Tournament Director Brewer Rowe.“Fans can watch double the tennis on our grass courts while still enjoying all of the unique amenities that make the Hall of Fame Open one of the most intimate environments on tour.”

Title: Iga Swiatek escapes junior doubles partner Caty McNally at Wimbledon
Description:
After losing the first set from 4-1 up, Swiatek rolled to a three-set win to set another showdown with Danielle Collins.ByTENNIS.comPublished Jul 03, 2025 copy_link

Published Jul 03, 2025

© 2025 Robert Prange

Iga Swiatek avoided the upset bug that has bitten many of tennis' top players at Wimbledon on Thursday as she rallied from a set down in a 5-7, 6-2, 6-1 victory over American Caty McNally.With five Top 10 seeds already out of the women's event over the first three days of the tournament, Swiatek looked as though she might join them as she cut a frustrated figure on Centre Court over the first hour of play, letting a 4-1 first-set lead slip away against a player she knows well.McNally was a junior peer, and rival, of Swiatek; she beat Swiatek in the semifinals of the 2018 junior French Open, where they teamed up to win the doubles title. But their professional paths diverged greatly since then. While Swiatek soared to the top of the WTA rankings, McNally found her greatest success in doubles with a career-high ranking of No. 53 in singles, and has been working her way back following a major elbow injury that necessitated surgery last year.Ranked outside the Top 1,000 in the world when she came back to tennis in November, McNally missed five Grand Slam tournaments before returning at the Australian Open in January on a protected ranking, and her 6-3, 6-1 win over Great Britain's Jodie Burrage in the first round was her first victory at a major since Melbourne in 2023.That lack of high-level match play showed for McNally over sets two and three, as she was unable to sustain the level required to earn a first career Top 10 win.

A post shared by Tennis (@tennischannel)

Swiatek took control of the match in the second set by breaking for 2-0 in a marathon McNally service game that featured six break points, and, at one stage, won seven straight games. Swiatek lost just three points on serve in the second set, and saved all five break points she faced in the decider, all of which came once she was already ahead 4-0.She finished the match with her fifth ace.Another American whom Swiatek knows well awaits. She will face Danielle Collins for a spot in the second week. Swiatek is 7-2 against the former Top 10-ranked American, but the pair have had several high-profile matches in the last year.Read more: Why did Danielle Collins change her Instagram profile picture to an Iga Swiatek handshake photo?Drama accompanied Swiatek's win over Collins at the Paris Olympics last summer, where Collins accused Swiatek of "fakeness" as she retired with an injury, and Collins dethroned then-defending champion Swiatek in Rome with a 6-1, 7-5 third-round effort this spring.
